question:
A 3-week-old girl delivered at term with no complications is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 1-
week history of yellow eyes and skin, tan-colored stools, and dark brown urine. The newborn has been breast-feeding
without difficulty. She is alert and appears to be in no distress. She is at the 50th percentile for length and weight.
Physical examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice. There is mild hepatomegaly; the spleen is not palpable.
Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin 14.4 g/dL
Hematocrit 43%
Leukocyte count 8000/mm³
Serum Albumin 3.5 g/dL
Serum Total Bilirubinc14 mg/dL
Direct Bilirubin 12.5 mg/dL
AST 50 U/L
ALT 45 U/L

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

(A) Biliary atresia
(B) Crigler-Najjar syndrome, type I
(C) Gilbert syndrome
(D) Hemolytic disease of the newborn
(E) Physiologic jaundice

metadata.medical_code_description: Congenital absence/obliteration of the extrahepatic bile ducts causing neonatal cholestasis, typically presenting in the first weeks of life with jaundice, dark urine, acholic (pale) stools, and hepatomegaly.

metadata.medical_code_description: Congenital obliteration or discontinuity of the extrahepatic (and sometimes intrahepatic) bile ducts leading to obstructive cholestasis in early infancy. Typical presentation is jaundice after the first 1–2 weeks of life with predominantly direct (conjugated) hyperbilirubinemia, dark urine, acholic/pale (tan) stools, and hepatomegaly; requires urgent evaluation and surgical management (e.g., Kasai portoenterostomy) to prevent progressive biliary cirrhosis.
metadata.diagnosis_explanation: This infant has cholestatic jaundice (total bilirubin 14 mg/dL with markedly elevated direct bilirubin 12.5 mg/dL). The presence of tan/acholic stools indicates lack of bile pigment reaching the intestine, and dark brown urine indicates water-soluble conjugated bilirubin being excreted by the kidneys—both classic for extrahepatic biliary obstruction. Onset at 2–6 weeks with hepatomegaly and only mild transaminase elevations is most consistent with biliary atresia rather than breast milk jaundice (unconjugated, normal stool/urine color) or physiologic jaundice (earlier, unconjugated).

question:
A 3-week-old girl delivered at term with no complications is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 1-
week history of yellow eyes and skin, tan-colored stools, and dark brown urine. The newborn has been breast-feeding
without difficulty. She is alert and appears to be in no distress. She is at the 50th percentile for length and weight.
Physical examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice. There is mild hepatomegaly; the spleen is not palpable.
Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14.4 g/dL
Hematocrit 43%
Leukocyte count 8000/mm³
Serum Albumin 3.5 g/dL
Serum Total Bilirubinc14 mg/dL
Direct Bilirubin 12.5 mg/dL
AST 50 U/L
ALT 45 U/L

What would be the patient's diagnosis based on the information provided?

metadata.medical_code_description: Congenital obstruction or absence of the extrahepatic bile ducts (biliary atresia), typically presenting in the first weeks of life with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, dark urine, pale/acholic stools, jaundice, and hepatomegaly.

question:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after blood pressure measurements were
175/105 mm Hg and 185/110 mm Hg 1 and 3 weeks ago, respectively. She has well-controlled type 2 diabetes
mellitus. Her blood pressure now is 175/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities.
Antihypertensive therapy is started, but her blood pressure remains elevated at her next visit 3 weeks later. Laboratory
studies show increased plasma renin activity; the erythrocyte sedimentation rate and serum electrolytes are within the
reference ranges. Angiography shows a high-grade stenosis of the proximal right renal artery; the left renal artery
appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

(A) Atherosclerosis
(B) Congenital renal artery hypoplasia
(C) Fibromuscular dysplasia
(D) Takayasu arteritis
(E) Temporal arteritis

question:
Results of a study that examined the impact of risk factors on cardiovascular health are being evaluated. In the study,
serum LDL-cholesterol (LDL) concentration is found to have a correlation of 0.6 with serum high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP) concentration. Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between
LDL concentration and hs-CRP concentration based on this finding?

(A) Higher LDL concentrations are associated with higher hs-CRP concentrations
(B) Higher LDL concentrations are associated with lower hs-CRP concentrations
(C) Higher LDL concentrations cause higher hs-CRP concentrations
(D) Higher LDL concentrations cause lower hs-CRP concentrations
correct_response: (A) Higher LDL concentrations are associated with higher hs-CRP concentrations

question:
A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a health maintenance examination. He has no personal or family history
of major medical illnesses. He has never smoked cigarettes. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation
of 98%. Physical examination shows plethoric skin and splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin 21.1 g/dL
Hematocrit 61%
Leukocyte count 15,000/mm³
Segmented neutrophils 68%
Basophils 4%
Lymphocytes 28%
Platelet count 501,000/mm³
Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase increased
A peripheral blood smear shows occasional giant platelets. 

The primary hematologic defect in this patient most likely 
occurred in which of the following cells?

(A) Erythroid progenitor
(B) Hematopoietic stem
(C) Lymphatic progenitor
(D) Megakaryocyte progenitor
(E) Pluripotent stem

question:
A 21-year-old man comes to the emergency department in the winter because of headache, nausea, and dizziness for
4 hours. He has not had fever, chills, or shortness of breath. He has no history of major medical illness. He lives in a
basement apartment of a three-story house. He smokes 1½ packs of cigarettes daily. Physical examination shows no
abnormalities. It is most appropriate for the physician to ask the patient for more information about which of the
following historical factors?

(A) Occupational exposure
(B) Substance use
(C) Travel
(D) Type of home heating
(E) Use of over-the-counter medication

metadata.medical_code_name: Toxic effect of carbon monoxide, unspecified, accidental (unintentional), initial encounter
metadata.medical_code_description: Accidental toxic effect from inhalation of carbon monoxide from an unspecified source (commonly malfunctioning furnace/space heater/indoor combustion) presenting on initial encounter; classically causes wintertime headache, nausea, dizziness with normal exam and no fever.
metadata.key_historical_factor_to_clarify: Recent exposure to indoor combustion in an enclosed space (e.g., faulty gas furnace/space heater, blocked chimney/vent, use of generator/grill indoors) and whether other household members/pets have similar symptoms or symptoms improve when leaving the apartment.
why_other_history_is_lower_priority_here: Infectious history (fever/chills, respiratory symptoms, sick contacts) is less helpful because the presentation is afebrile with a normal exam and has a strong seasonal/environmental trigger (winter, basement dwelling).

Primary neurologic causes (e.g., stroke, meningitis) are less immediately suggested because there are no focal deficits, neck stiffness, or altered mental status; the symptom cluster is classic for mild CO exposure.
GI/foodborne exposure questions are less likely to explain the triad of headache + dizziness + nausea occurring in winter in an enclosed living space; CO better unifies the symptoms and setting.

Smoking history is relevant but does not fully explain acute onset of neurologic symptoms over 4 hours; it should prompt CO consideration but the key missing piece is an indoor CO source/exposure pattern.

question:
A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a long history of pain with menses. The pain occurs on the
first day of her 5-day menstrual period and lasts all day. She rates the pain as 10 on a 10-point scale. The most
appropriate initial pharmacotherapy to relieve this patient's pain has which of the following mechanisms of action?

(A) Inhibition of estrogen synthesis
(B) Inhibition of 11β-hydroxylase activity
(C) Inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis
(D) Stimulation of follicle-stimulating hormone synthesis
(E) Stimulation of luteinizing hormone synthesis

(B) Inhibition of 11β-hydroxylase activity

metadata.medical_code_description: Painful menstruation without an identifiable pelvic pathology, typically due to increased endometrial prostaglandin production causing uterine contractions and ischemic pain (often treated initially with NSAIDs that inhibit cyclooxygenase and decrease prostaglandin synthesis).

metadata.medical_code_description: Primary dysmenorrhea is painful menstruation without an underlying pelvic pathology, commonly caused by increased endometrial prostaglandin production leading to uterine hypercontractility and ischemic pain. The appropriate initial pharmacotherapy is an NSAID (eg, ibuprofen, naproxen), which relieves pain by inhibiting cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2) and thereby decreasing prostaglandin synthesis.

metadata.medical_code_description: Painful menstruation (crampy pelvic pain) due to increased endometrial prostaglandin production leading to uterine hypercontractility and ischemia; typically treated with NSAIDs that inhibit cyclooxygenase (COX-1/COX-2) to reduce prostaglandin synthesis.

question:
A 3800-g (8-lb 6-oz) newborn is delivered vaginally at 39 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy. Apgar scores are 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The newborn is crying, has pink skin, and appears vigorous. Physical examination shows a vagina and also a structure that appears to be a penis, with the urethra located at the base near the opening of the vagina. Chromosomal analysis is ordered. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the intersex findings in this newborn if the karyotype is found to be 46,XX?

(A) 17α-Hydroxyprogesterone deficiency
(B) Increased concentration of müllerian-inhibiting substance
(C) Maternal androgen exposure
(D) Presence of the sex-determining region Y gene
(E) 5α-Reductase deficiency
question_context: A 3800-g (8-lb 6-oz) newborn is delivered vaginally at 39 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy. Apgar scores are 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The newborn is crying, has pink skin, and appears vigorous. (D) Presence of the sex-determining region Y gene
(E) 5α-Reductase deficiency

metadata.medical_code_name: Congenital adrenogenital disorders associated with enzyme deficiency
metadata.medical_code_description: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to an adrenal steroidogenesis enzyme defect (most commonly 21-hydroxylase deficiency), leading to excess adrenal androgen production and virilization/ambiguous genitalia in a 46,XX newborn.

metadata.medical_code_name: Congenital adrenogenital disorders associated with enzyme deficiency
metadata.medical_code_description: In a 46,XX newborn with ambiguous/virilized external genitalia (eg, phallic-appearing structure with the urethral opening near the vaginal introitus), the most common cause is congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most often due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. The enzyme defect decreases cortisol (± aldosterone) synthesis, increasing ACTH and adrenal steroid precursors that are shunted into androgen production. This causes prenatal androgen excess and virilization of external genitalia in genetic females, while internal female reproductive organs are typically present (no MIS). Severe forms can present with salt-wasting (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, dehydration) in the neonatal period.

What is most likely cause of the intersex findings in this newborn if the karyotype is found to be 46,XX?
question_context: A 3800-g (8-lb 6-oz) newborn is delivered vaginally at 39 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy. Apgar scores are 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The newborn is crying, has pink skin, and appears vigorous. Physical examination shows a vagina and also a structure that appears to be a penis, with the urethra located at the base near the opening of the vagina. Chromosomal analysis is ordered. What is most likely cause of the intersex findings in this newborn if the karyotype is found to be 46,XX?

metadata.medical_code_name: Congenital adrenogenital disorders associated with enzyme deficiency
metadata.medical_code_description: Autosomal recessive congenital adrenal hyperplasia (most commonly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency) causing excess adrenal androgen production, leading to virilization/ambiguous genitalia in a 46,XX newborn (often with potential salt-wasting crisis if severe).

question:
A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 12-hour history of chest pain. Physical examination shows
no abnormalities. Serum studies show an increased troponin I concentration. The diagnosis of myocardial infarction
is made. It is suspected that this patient's condition deteriorated as a result of ischemia-reperfusion injury. The
increased serum troponin I concentration in this patient most likely occurred as a result of which of the following
processes?

(A) Increased enzyme secretion
(B) Increased enzyme synthesis
(C) Karyolysis
(D) Lysis of the endoplasmic reticulum
(E) Lysis of the plasma membrane
(F) Mitochondrial swelling

question:
A randomized clinical trial is conducted to compare wound healing and cosmetic differences between two surgical
procedures for closing skin wounds following cesarean delivery. A total of 1000 women undergoing cesarean delivery
during a 6-month period are enrolled in the study, which was 85% of the total number of patients undergoing the
procedure. The results show a wound infection rate of 12 cases per 1000 women for Procedure A and 18 cases per
1000 women for Procedure B. Which of the following is the best estimate of the absolute risk reduction for wound
infection following Procedure A compared with Procedure B?

(A) (18/1000) – (12/1000)
(B) 0.85 × (12/1000)
(C) 0.85 × (18/1000)
(D) [0.85 × (18/1000–12/1000)]
(E) [(1.2/100) – (1.8/100)]/(1.8/100)

question:
A 4-year-old girl with type 1 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department by her father because of a 4-
hour episode of restlessness, sweating, and confusion that occurred during the night. Yesterday, he allowed her to eat
cupcakes and cotton candy at a county fair. At her bedtime that evening, he increased her dose of subcutaneous
intermediate-acting and long-acting insulin. Her symptoms began 6 hours later, then resolved spontaneously. After
being informed this morning of this nighttime episode, the mother insisted the father bring the patient to the hospital.
On arrival, the patient is alert. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Her
fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 72 mg/dL. Urinalysis is negative for glucose and ketones. Which of the
following is the most likely explanation for this patient's nighttime symptoms?

(A) Hyperglycemia caused by increased glucose consumption
(B) Hyperglycemia caused by increased glycogen metabolism
(C) Hyperglycemia caused by insufficient exogenous insulin
(D) Hypoglycemia caused by excess exogenous insulin
(E) Hypoglycemia caused by excessive renal glucose loss
(F) Hypoglycemia caused by increased glucagon secretion
(G) Nightmare disorder
(H) Sleep terror disorder
correct_response: (D) Hypoglycemia caused by excess exogenous insulin

question:
A male newborn is delivered at term to a 28-year-old primigravid woman. Physical examination shows a broad, flat
nose; low-set ears; a receding chin; prominent infraorbital folds; and bilateral abdominal masses. The newborn
develops cyanosis, difficulty breathing, and polyuria and dies 24 hours after birth. At autopsy, examination shows
pulmonary hypoplasia and enlarged, polycystic kidneys. Genetic testing shows two copies of a gene having a
pathogenic mutation with a disease incidence rate in the general population of 1 in 10,000. Which of the following
best describes the mutation occurrence rate for this newborn's disease?

(A) 1/100
(B) 1/400
(C) 1/1000
(D) 1/4000
(E) 1/10,000
question_context:
A male newborn is delivered at term to a 28-year-old primigravid woman. Physical examination shows a broad, flat
nose; low-set ears; a receding chin; prominent infraorbital folds; and bilateral abdominal masses. The newborn
develops cyanosis, difficulty breathing, and polyuria and dies 24 hours after birth. At autopsy, examination shows
pulmonary hypoplasia and enlarged, polycystic kidneys. Genetic testing shows two copies of a gene having a
pathogenic mutation with a disease incidence rate in the general population of 1 in 10,000. Which of the following
best describes the mutation occurrence rate for this newborn's disease?

metadata.medical_code_description: Autosomal recessive (infantile) polycystic kidney disease presenting in the neonatal period with enlarged bilateral polycystic kidneys; often associated with oligohydramnios/Potter sequence and pulmonary hypoplasia, frequently leading to respiratory failure and early neonatal death.

question:
A male newborn is delivered at term to a 28-year-old primigravid woman. Physical examination shows a broad, flat
nose; low-set ears; a receding chin; prominent infraorbital folds; and bilateral abdominal masses. The newborn
develops cyanosis, difficulty breathing, and polyuria and dies 24 hours after birth. At autopsy, examination shows
pulmonary hypoplasia and enlarged, polycystic kidneys. Genetic testing shows two copies of a gene having a
pathogenic mutation with a disease incidence rate in the general population of 1 in 10,000. What is the mutation occurrence rate for this newborn's disease? Explain each item.

(A) 1/100
(B) 1/400
(C) 1/1000
(D) 1/4000
(E) 1/10,000
question_context:
A male newborn is delivered at term to a 28-year-old primigravid woman. Physical examination shows a broad, flat
nose; low-set ears; a receding chin; prominent infraorbital folds; and bilateral abdominal masses. The newborn
develops cyanosis, difficulty breathing, and polyuria and dies 24 hours after birth. At autopsy, examination shows
pulmonary hypoplasia and enlarged, polycystic kidneys. Genetic testing shows two copies of a gene having a
pathogenic mutation with a disease incidence rate in the general population of 1 in 10,000. What is the mutation occurrence rate for this newborn's disease? Explain each item.

metadata.medical_code_description:
This presentation is most consistent with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), which can cause enlarged bilateral polycystic kidneys, pulmonary hypoplasia (often due to oligohydramnios/Potter sequence), and neonatal respiratory failure.

Given a disease incidence of 1 in 10,000 in the general population for an autosomal recessive condition:
- Incidence (affected frequency) = q^2 = 1/10,000.
- Mutant allele frequency = q = sqrt(1/10,000) = 1/100 = 0.01 (i.e., ~1% of alleles in the population are the pathogenic allele).
- Normal allele frequency = p = 1 − q = 0.99.
- Carrier frequency = 2pq = 2(0.99)(0.01) = 0.0198 ≈ 1/50 (about 2% of the population are carriers).

Thus, the mutation (pathogenic allele) occurrence rate in the population is q = 0.01 (≈1 in 100 alleles), and the carrier rate is approximately 1 in 50 people.

metadata.medical_code_description: Congenital (typically autosomal recessive) polycystic kidney disease presenting in infancy/neonatal period with enlarged cystic kidneys; can be associated with oligohydramnios sequence (Potter facies) and pulmonary hypoplasia due to impaired fetal urine production.

question:
A previously healthy 64-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after the sudden onset of severe
flank pain. He has no history of similar pain or serious illness. He takes no medications. He appears to be in distress.
His pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 168/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a soft abdomen with left sided tenderness. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a small ureteric calculus.
Analgesic therapy is initiated and the pain resolves 1 hour later. The urine is then strained and a uric acid calculus is
found. Which of the following processes is most likely impaired in this patient?

(A) Bile salt metabolism
(B) Cholesterol metabolism
(C) Cytochrome P450 activity
(D) Purine metabolism
(E) Urea cycle
question_context:

(A) Bile salt metabolism
(B) Cholesterol metabolism
(C) Cytochrome P450 activity
(D) Purine metabolism
(E) Urea cycle

metadata.medical_code_description: Presence of a urinary stone (urolithiasis) located within the ureter, which can cause acute flank pain and hematuria due to ureteral obstruction and mucosal irritation.

question:
A 32-year-old woman with hypothyroidism comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of cold intolerance, constipation, and severe fatigue. She also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight gain during this period. Her current medication is daily levothyroxine. She also started taking calcium carbonate supplements 2 months ago for osteopenia of the lumbar spine. At that time, serum concentrations of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (FT4) were within the reference ranges. Today, physical examination shows coarse, dry skin. Serum studies show a TSH concentration of 16.6 μU/mL and FT4 concentration of 0.3 ng/dL. Which of the following pharmacokinetic changes of levothyroxine is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?

(A) Decreased absorption
(B) Decreased distribution
(C) Decreased elimination
(D) Increased distribution
(E) Increased elimination
(F) Increased metabolism
question_context: A 32-year-old woman with hypothyroidism comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of cold intolerance, constipation, and severe fatigue. Serum studies show a TSH concentration of 16.6 μU/mL and FT4 concentration of 0.3 ng/dL. Which of the following pharmacokinetic changes of levothyroxine is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
options:
(A) Decreased absorption
(B) Decreased distribution
(C) Decreased elimination
(D) Increased distribution
(E) Increased elimination
(F) Increased metabolism

metadata.medical_code_description: A disorder characterized by insufficient thyroid hormone production (or inadequate thyroid hormone effect), leading to an elevated TSH and low free T4, with symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, constipation, dry/coarse skin, and cold intolerance.

metadata.medical_code_description: Decreased thyroid hormone effect causing an elevated TSH and low free T4. In this vignette, the patient’s worsening hypothyroidism is most consistent with reduced oral levothyroxine bioavailability due to impaired gastrointestinal absorption from concomitant calcium carbonate (a cation that binds/adsorbs levothyroxine in the gut), leading to inadequate systemic exposure despite the same prescribed dose.

At that time, serum concentrations of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (FT4) were within the reference ranges. Today, physical examination shows coarse, dry skin. question_context: A 32-year-old woman with hypothyroidism comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of cold intolerance, constipation, and severe fatigue. She also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight gain during this period. Her current medication is daily levothyroxine. She also started taking calcium carbonate supplements 2 months ago for osteopenia of the lumbar spine. At that time, serum concentrations of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (FT4) were within the reference ranges. Today, physical examination shows coarse, dry skin. Serum studies show a TSH concentration of 16.6 μU/mL and FT4 concentration of 0.3 ng/dL. What pharmacokinetic changes of levothyroxine caused the patient’s condition?

metadata.medical_code_description: A disorder characterized by insufficient production of thyroid hormone, leading to elevated TSH and low free thyroxine (FT4) with clinical features such as fatigue, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and dry/coarse skin; etiology not specified.

question:
A 48-year-old man comes to the physician requesting treatment for alcohol withdrawal. He reports a 30-year history of consuming 6 to 10 beers daily. He has had two citations for driving while intoxicated. He has previously experienced alcohol-associated seizures and withdrawal symptoms. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows palmar erythema. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy in this patient most likely has which of the following mechanisms?

(A) Blockade of dopamine receptors
(B) Decreased activity of dopamine transporters
(C) Enhancement of the effect of postsynaptic γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA)
(D) Increased GABA transaminase activity
(E) Inhibition of glutamate release
(F) Inhibition of serotonin reuptake
(G) Opening of glutamate channels
(H) Stimulation of 5-hydroxytryptophan receptors
correct_response: (C) Enhancement of the effect of postsynaptic γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA)

metadata.medical_code_description: This presentation is most consistent with alcohol dependence with a history of clinically significant withdrawal (including prior withdrawal seizures). First-line pharmacotherapy for alcohol withdrawal is a benzodiazepine (eg, diazepam, chlordiazepoxide, lorazepam), which acts as a positive allosteric modulator of the GABA-A receptor, increasing the FREQUENCY of chloride channel opening to restore inhibitory tone and prevent seizures/delirium tremens. Other common answer choices are less likely because: (1) naltrexone (opioid receptor antagonist), acamprosate (modulates glutamatergic/NMDA), and disulfiram (aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibition) are used for maintenance treatment of alcohol use disorder/relapse prevention rather than acute withdrawal; (2) antipsychotics (D2 antagonists) can worsen seizure threshold and do not treat the underlying withdrawal physiology; (3) beta-blockers/clonidine may reduce autonomic symptoms but do not prevent seizures or delirium tremens; (4) barbiturates also enhance GABA-A but are not first-line due to narrower therapeutic index and higher respiratory depression risk (reserved for refractory cases).

question: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician requesting treatment for alcohol withdrawal. He reports a 30-year history of consuming 6 to 10 beers daily. correct_response: Enhancement of the effect of postsynaptic γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA)

metadata.medical_code_description: Alcohol dependence with a withdrawal state (alcohol withdrawal syndrome), without further specification of associated features such as delirium or perceptual disturbance.
metadata.mechanism: Benzodiazepines are positive allosteric modulators of the GABA-A receptor that increase the FREQUENCY of chloride channel opening, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission.
metadata.rationale: This patient has severe alcohol use disorder and a history of alcohol-withdrawal seizures, which places him at high risk for recurrent seizures during withdrawal. First-line therapy to prevent/treat alcohol withdrawal symptoms and seizures is a benzodiazepine (eg, diazepam or chlordiazepoxide) due to cross-tolerance with alcohol at the GABA-A receptor and reliable reduction of seizure risk.

question:

She travels frequently and works long hours. She says that her meals are usually fast food. She leads a sedentary lifestyle. She often forgets to measure her blood glucose concentration. Her last hemoglobin A1c was measured as 8.4%. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician to help this patient improve her diabetic control?

She has not had itching. During the past 3 weeks, she has had two similar, milder episodes that resolved without treatment within 24 to 72 hours. Six weeks ago, she began treatment with an ACE inhibitor for hypertension. She has seasonal allergies. metadata.medical_code_name: Adverse effect of angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors, initial encounter
metadata.medical_code_description: This code is used for an adverse (non–dose-related) effect from ACE inhibitor therapy. In this clinical context, ACE inhibitors decrease bradykinin breakdown, leading to bradykinin-mediated angioedema (typically without urticaria or pruritus) that can involve the lips, tongue, and airway.

question:
A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue and poor appetite; she has had a 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight loss during this period. Abdominal examination shows moderate splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 185,000/mm³ (65% segmented neutrophils with 6% blasts and promyelocytes). Cytogenetic analysis of a bone marrow aspirate shows the presence of the Philadelphia (Ph¹) chromosome in myelocytes. Which of the following mechanisms best accounts for the formation of the Philadelphia (Ph¹) chromosome in this patient?

(A) Nondisjunction
(B) Recombination
(C) Sister chromatid exchange
(D) Telomere breakage
(E) Transposon insertion

metadata.medical_code_name: Chronic myeloid leukemia, BCR/ABL-positive, not having achieved remission
metadata.medical_code_description: A myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the presence of the BCR-ABL1 fusion (Philadelphia chromosome) resulting from t(9;22), typically presenting with marked leukocytosis and splenomegaly; this code specifies disease not having achieved remission.

mechanism_best_accounts_for_Philadelphia.mechanism: Reciprocal chromosomal translocation t(9;22)(q34;q11) with creation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene (constitutively active tyrosine kinase).
mechanism_best_accounts_for_Philadelphia.pathogenesis_one_liner: DNA double-strand breaks followed by mis-repair (e.g., nonhomologous end joining) incorrectly joins segments of chromosomes 9 and 22, generating BCR-ABL.

why_this_and_not_others.why_not: A deletion removes genetic material; the Philadelphia chromosome is defined by a balanced reciprocal translocation producing a fusion gene, not a simple loss.
An inversion flips a segment within the same chromosome; CML requires exchange between two different chromosomes (9 and 22).
Amplification increases copy number (e.g., HER2); the key lesion in CML is a fusion (BCR-ABL), not increased copies of a normal gene.
Single-nucleotide changes can activate oncogenes (e.g., RAS) but do not explain the cytogenetically visible Philadelphia chromosome.
Transposons insert sequences, but the classic, testable mechanism for Ph+ CML is a reciprocal translocation creating BCR-ABL.

Clinically associated with marked leukocytosis with left shift, splenomegaly, constitutional symptoms (fatigue, weight loss), and progression risk to blast crisis.

question:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of failure to thrive. He also has had loose, fatty, foul-smelling stools and a cough during the past 2 weeks. He is at the 30th percentile for height and 10th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Laboratory studies show steatorrhea and a sweat chloride concentration of 80 mmol/L. A chest x-ray shows hyperinflation. Sputum culture grows Haemophilus influenzae and Staphylococcus aureus. Secretion of which of the following substances is most likely to be decreased in this patient?

(A) Bicarbonate
(B) Gastric acid
(C) Glucagon
(D) Insulin
(E) Intrinsic factor

metadata.medical_code_description: Autosomal recessive disorder caused by CFTR dysfunction leading to impaired chloride transport with dehydrated, thick respiratory secretions, recurrent pulmonary infections (often including Staphylococcus aureus and Haemophilus influenzae), hyperinflation/obstructive lung disease, and commonly associated exocrine pancreatic insufficiency causing malabsorption/steatorrhea and failure to thrive; classically associated with elevated sweat chloride.

question: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of failure to thrive. He also has had loose, fatty, foul-smelling stools and a cough during the past 2 weeks. He is at the 30th percentile for height and 10th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. What substance has a reduced secretion in this patient and explain why?
question_context: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of failure to thrive. He also has had loose, fatty, foul-smelling stools and a cough during the past 2 weeks. metadata.medical_code_description: An autosomal recessive disorder caused by CFTR dysfunction leading to abnormal chloride transport and thickened secretions, with pulmonary involvement such as chronic cough, airway obstruction/hyperinflation, and recurrent respiratory infections (eg, Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae). In affected exocrine tissues (eg, pancreatic ducts/airways), decreased CFTR-mediated chloride secretion (and reduced accompanying water movement) produces dehydrated, viscous mucus that obstructs ducts/airways, contributing to malabsorption/steatorrhea and chronic lung disease.

question:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of nosebleeds and easy bruisability. His older brother has had similar episodes. He is at the 30th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows nasal and gingival bleeding and several ecchymoses over the trunk and upper and lower extremities in various stages of healing. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 300,000/mm³ (N=150,000–400,000). Platelet adhesion testing shows a normal response to ristocetin, but aggregation does not occur in response to thrombin; platelet morphology is normal. Prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time are within the reference ranges. A defect in which of the following is the most likely cause of the findings in this patient?

(A) Factor VII (proconvertin)
(B) Fibrinogen
(C) Glycoprotein IIb-IIIa
(D) Granule storage pool
(E) von Willebrand factor
question_context: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of nosebleeds and easy bruisability. His older brother has had similar episodes. options:
(A) Factor VII (proconvertin)
(B) Fibrinogen
(C) Glycoprotein IIb-IIIa
(D) Granule storage pool
(E) von Willebrand factor

metadata.medical_code_description: Disorders of platelet function with normal or near-normal platelet count and morphology, causing mucocutaneous bleeding (e.g., epistaxis, gingival bleeding, easy bruising); includes inherited platelet aggregation defects such as Glanzmann thrombasthenia due to glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (integrin αIIbβ3) dysfunction.

metadata.medical_code_description: Inherited or acquired platelet function disorders with normal or near-normal platelet count, causing mucocutaneous bleeding (eg, epistaxis, gingival bleeding, easy bruising). metadata.medical_code_description: Disorders of platelet function (with normal or near-normal platelet count) due to qualitative defects in platelet receptors or signaling pathways, leading to impaired platelet plug formation and mucocutaneous bleeding; includes conditions such as Glanzmann thrombasthenia (GPIIb/IIIa deficiency) and related qualitative platelet dysfunctions.

question:
A previously healthy 45-year-old woman who works as a park ranger comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of shortness of breath, even at rest. She has lived in the mountains at 10,000 feet above sea level for 2 years; the physician’s office is located at sea level. Her pulse is 85/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/90 mm Hg. Physical examination while sitting upright shows jugular venous distention and 2+ pedal edema. During the past 2 years, which of the following has most likely decreased in this patient?

(A) Height of P waves in lead I of the patient's ECG
(B) Height of R waves in lead V₁ of the patient's ECG
(C) Hematocrit
(D) Pulmonary vascular resistance
(E) Right ventricular diastolic compliance
(F) Right ventricular wall thickness
question_context: A previously healthy 45-year-old woman who works as a park ranger comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of shortness of breath, even at rest. (B) Height of R waves in lead V₁ of the patient's ECG
(C) Hematocrit
(D) Pulmonary vascular resistance
(E) Right ventricular diastolic compliance
(F) Right ventricular wall thickness

metadata.medical_code_description: Chronic right ventricular hypertrophy and/or right-sided heart failure due to pulmonary hypertension secondary to disorders of the lungs or pulmonary vasculature (eg, chronic hypoxic vasoconstriction at high altitude), often presenting with jugular venous distention and peripheral edema.

question:
A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of cough and unintentional weight loss. Rhonchi are heard posteriorly over the right upper thorax. A chest x-ray shows an 8-cm cavity in the right upper lobe and hilar lymphadenopathy. Ziehl-Neelsen staining of an induced sputum specimen shows acid-fast bacilli. The patient begins treatment with four antimycobacterial drugs, including rifampin. Synthesis of which of the following components of the suspected pathogen is most likely directly inhibited by the rifampin in this patient's medication regimen?

(A) ATP
(B) Folic acid
(C) Peptidoglycan
(D) Protein
(E) RNA

question:
A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being hit by a motor vehicle while walking. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. During an exploratory laparotomy, a large laceration is found that includes the right and left lobes of the liver. Active bleeding is present. Compression of which of the following ligaments is most likely to decrease bleeding from the liver in this patient?

(A) Coronary
(B) Falciform
(C) Gastrohepatic
(D) Hepatoduodenal
(E) Triangular

question:
A 1-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fever and cough. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 140/min, and respirations are 54/min. Physical examination shows intercostal retractions. Wheezes are heard in all lung fields. A blood culture grows coagulase-negative, catalase-positive, gram-positive cocci in clusters. Which of the following best represents the infectious agent in this patient's blood culture?

(A) Staphylococcus aureus, contaminant
(B) Staphylococcus aureus, pathogen
(C) Staphylococcus epidermidis, contaminant
(D) Staphylococcus epidermidis, pathogen
(E) Streptococcus pneumoniae, contaminant
(F) Streptococcus pneumoniae, pathogen
(G) Streptococcus sanguis, contaminant
(H) Streptococcus sanguis, pathogen

question:
A new drug, Drug X, is being investigated to determine its pharmacokinetic properties in humans. A male participant who weighs 85 kg (187 lb) with 50 L of total body water begins treatment with an intravenous infusion of Drug X at the rate of 100 mg/h. metadata.calculation: For a constant IV infusion at steady state: Rate_in = Clearance (Cl) × C_ss. Given Rate_in = 100 mg/h and C_ss = 50 mg/L, Cl = 100 mg/h ÷ 50 mg/L = 2 L/h (units reduce to L/h).

question:
A 78-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit because of diverticulitis complicated by Escherichia coli sepsis. Treatment with ciprofloxacin is started. Three days later, her serum creatinine concentration has increased from 0.7 mg/dL on admission to 1.3 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows muddy brown casts. The most likely cause of the findings in this patient is ischemia of which of the following structures?

(A) Bowman capsule
(B) Glomerulus
(C) Interstitium
(D) Proximal tubule
(E) Renal vein

question:
A 34-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of increasing weakness, shortness of breath, and abdominal cramping. Current medications are prednisone and pyridostigmine. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 45/min, and respirations are 25/min and shallow. Her voice is soft and hypernasal, and she coughs weakly when swallowing water. Breath and heart sounds are normal. Pulmonary testing shows inability to generate a normal negative inspiratory force during forced inspiration. The abdomen is soft and nontender, with increased bowel sounds. Muscle strength is 4/5 diffusely, with severe, continuous, and diffuse fasciculations. Deep tendon reflexes are sluggish, but symmetric. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's weakness? 

(A) Aspiration pneumonia
(B) Guillain-Barré syndrome
(C) Insufficient dose of prednisone
(D) Motor neuron disease
(E) Pyridostigmine overdose

metadata.medical_code_description: Acute toxicity from anticholinesterase medications (eg, pyridostigmine) causing excess acetylcholine at synapses and the neuromuscular junction, leading to cholinergic findings (eg, bradycardia, abdominal cramping/diarrhea, fasciculations) and weakness/respiratory compromise.

question:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the office because she has had three first-trimester spontaneous abortions during the past 3 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show no endocrine abnormalities. Chromosomal analysis shows a paracentric inversion of the long arm of chromosome 1. Which of the following best describes this patient’s risk for early spontaneous abortions and a liveborn child with aneuploidy? 

(A) High Risk for Early Spontaneous Abortions: high Risk for Liveborn Child With Aneuploidy
(B) High Risk for Early Spontaneous Abortions: low Risk for Liveborn Child With Aneuploidy
(C) Low Risk for Early Spontaneous Abortions: high Risk for Liveborn Child With Aneuploidy
(D) Low Risk for Early Spontaneous Abortions: low Risk for Liveborn Child With Aneuploidy
correct_response: (B) High Risk for Early Spontaneous Abortions: low Risk for Liveborn Child With Aneuploidy

metadata.medical_code_description: Recurrent pregnancy loss (recurrent miscarriages), typically defined clinically as two or more consecutive spontaneous abortions; often evaluated for genetic, anatomic, endocrine, and autoimmune causes. In this case, a paracentric inversion carrier has increased risk of early spontaneous abortion due to nonviable recombinant gametes (dicentric/acentric products), with relatively low risk of a liveborn child with aneuploidy because most unbalanced conceptions are not compatible with survival.

metadata.medical_code_description: Recurrent pregnancy loss (typically defined as ≥2–3 consecutive spontaneous abortions), often due to causes such as parental chromosomal rearrangements. In a paracentric inversion, recombination can produce acentric/dicentric chromatids that are usually nonviable, increasing the risk of early miscarriage while conferring a low risk of a liveborn child with aneuploidy.

question:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for genetic counseling because of a family history of genetic disorders. He has no symptoms or history of major medical illness. The patient’s maternal grandfather died of Huntington disease at the age of 35 years. Genetic testing of the mother showed 19 triplet repeats on each huntingtin (HTT) allele (N=10–20). The patient’s paternal grandfather had colon cancer at the age of 30 years, and the father had numerous colon polyps at the age of 20 years treated with a colectomy. Genetic testing of the father shows heterozygosity for a frame-shift mutation in the APC gene. Physical examination of the patient shows abnormalities. Based on this patient’s risk for genetic disease, it is most appropriate for the physician to order which of the following genetic tests at this time?

(A) Analysis of triplet repeat sizes of HTT
(B) Full sequencing and rearrangement analysis of APC
(C) Full sequencing of HTT
(D) Specific testing for the APC frame-shift mutation
(E) It is not recommended to do predictive genetic testing on a minor
correct_response: (D) Specific testing for the APC frame-shift mutation

question:
A 25-year-old man comes to the office because of a 4-hour history of irritability, restlessness, tremor, and palpitations. He is a known user of amphetamines. His pulse is 120/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 150/100 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is sympathomimetic activity arising from which of the following? 

(A) Decreased intracellular metabolism of biogenic amines
(B) Decreased monoamine oxidase activity
(C) Decreased presynaptic receptor activation
(D) Increased intracellular metabolism of biogenic amines
(E) Increased presynaptic receptor activation
(F) Increased release of biogenic amines

metadata.medical_code_name: Other stimulant use, unspecified with intoxication, unspecified
metadata.medical_code_description: Acute intoxication due to a stimulant (eg, amphetamines) producing sympathomimetic toxicity such as agitation/irritability, restlessness, tremor, tachycardia, hypertension, and palpitations.

rationale.most_likely_mechanism: Amphetamines increase sympathomimetic activity primarily by increasing release of catecholamines (especially norepinephrine and dopamine) from presynaptic nerve terminals. They enter the presynaptic neuron via NET/DAT, displace monoamines from vesicles via VMAT, and reverse NET/DAT transport, raising synaptic NE/DA → tachycardia, hypertension, tremor, agitation.
why_other_common_choices_are_wrong: Blocking catecholamine reuptake (NET/DAT inhibition) is the primary mechanism of cocaine (and some antidepressants), not classic amphetamine’s main effect (which is increased release/reverse transport).
Inhibiting monoamine oxidase (MAO) decreases catecholamine breakdown and can increase NE/DA, but that is the mechanism of MAO inhibitors; it is not the primary mechanism of amphetamine intoxication.
Direct alpha/beta adrenergic receptor agonism describes drugs like epinephrine/phenylephrine (direct-acting) or ephedrine (mixed-acting); amphetamines are predominantly indirect-acting releasers.
Inhibiting COMT affects catecholamine metabolism mainly in peripheral tissues and is classically related to levodopa adjuncts (entacapone/tolcapone), not typical acute amphetamine toxicity.
Increasing acetylcholine release or activating muscarinic receptors would not cause this adrenergic toxidrome (would more likely cause bradycardia, bronchorrhea, miosis, diarrhea).

question: A 25-year-old man comes to the office because of a 4-hour history of irritability, restlessness, tremor, and palpitations. He is a known user of amphetamines. His pulse is 120/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 150/100 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. What causes the rising of sympathomimetic activity which then leads to the causation of this patient's symptoms?

metadata.medical_code_name: Other stimulant abuse with intoxication, unspecified
metadata.medical_code_description: Abuse of other stimulants (eg, amphetamines) with acute intoxication, presenting with sympathomimetic findings such as irritability, restlessness, tremor, tachycardia, hypertension, and palpitations.

question:
A 5-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother because of a 6-hour history of bloody diarrhea. She is interactive and in no acute distress. Her blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows normoactive bowel sounds. Stool cultures are obtained, and the patient's mother is advised to give the girl plenty of fluids. Five days later, the patient develops decreased urine output and is brought back to the office. Her blood pressure is now 135/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL (N=11–15)
Hematocrit 26% (N=28%–45%)
Platelet count 45,000/mm³ (N=150,000–400,000)
Serum creatinine 3.3 mg/dL (N=0.3–0.7)

Which of the following infectious agents is the most likely cause of these findings?

(A) Campylobacter jejuni
(B) Escherichia coli
(C) Rotavirus
(D) Salmonella enterica serovar enteritidis
(E) Yersinia pestis

metadata.medical_code_description: Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS): classically follows bloody diarrheal illness and presents with the triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (low hemoglobin/hematocrit with pallor), thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury (elevated creatinine, oliguria), often with new/worsening hypertension. Most commonly triggered by Shiga toxin–producing enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC), classically E. coli O157:H7 (less commonly Shigella dysenteriae type 1).

question:
A 78-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-week history of jaundice. CT scan of the abdomen shows a mass suggestive of pancreatic cancer. Three hours later, the on-call physician enters the patient's room to discuss the prognosis and obtain consent for a biopsy scheduled for the next morning. On entering the room, the physician greets the patient and her husband. The physician then learns that the patient speaks only Mandarin. Her husband is fluent in Mandarin and English. The hospital interpreter is not available until tomorrow morning. The patient's husband appears anxious and insists that the physician speaks to him and allows him to serve as an interpreter for his wife. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

(A) Allow the patient's husband to serve as an interpreter
(B) Consult the hospital ethics committee
(C) Explain to the husband that information cannot be provided until the hospital interpreter arrives in the
morning
(D) Use a telephone interpreter service

metadata.medical_code_description: ICD-10-CM Z60.3 is used for problems related to social environment, including difficulties due to cultural/language barriers that affect communication and access to appropriate medical care (eg, need for professional medical interpretation to ensure accurate communication and valid informed consent).
metadata.next_step_management: Do not use the husband as the interpreter for obtaining informed consent. Arrange a qualified medical interpreter (eg, telephone/video interpretation services now, or defer the consent discussion until the hospital interpreter is available tomorrow morning since the biopsy is not emergent).
metadata.rationale: Valid informed consent requires that the patient (not the spouse) receives and understands the information in her preferred language, with an opportunity to ask questions free of undue influence. Family-member interpretation risks errors, omissions, and bias/coercion—particularly when discussing prognosis and consenting to an invasive procedure. Family interpretation is generally reserved only for true emergencies when no qualified interpreter is available and delaying care would risk serious harm.

metadata.medical_code_description: ICD-10-CM Z60.3 is used for problems related to social environment such as acculturation/language barriers that interfere with appropriate medical care (eg, inability to communicate in the local language). In this scenario, informed consent for a non-emergent invasive procedure (biopsy) should be obtained using a qualified medical interpreter (eg, in-person, phone, or video). Family members (including a spouse) should not serve as interpreters for consent discussions due to risks of inaccuracy, omission, or coercion; therefore, the appropriate next step is to arrange a professional interpreter and delay the consent discussion until one is available (or use an approved remote interpreter service immediately if available).

question:
A 4-year-old boy develops fever 3 weeks after being admitted to the hospital for induction chemotherapy for treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Chemotherapy medications are L-asparaginase, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and vincristine. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 122/min, and respirations are 24/min. Physical examination shows pallor, alopecia, and ulcerations over the gums. A central venous catheter with entry site in the right upper chest is present but has no surrounding erythema. A blood culture grows gram-negative rods after 36 hours. Which of the following underlying mechanisms is the most likely cause of this patient's susceptibility to infection?

(A) Deficiency of terminal complement
(B) Hypogammaglobulinemia
(C) Impaired T-lymphocyte function
(D) Inhibition of tumor necrosis factor α function
(E) Neutropenia

metadata.medical_code_description: Severe neutropenia (marked reduction in circulating granulocytes/neutrophils) caused by cytotoxic chemotherapy, resulting in impaired innate immune defense—especially reduced neutrophil-mediated phagocytosis and killing of bacteria—and increased susceptibility to infections (commonly gram-negative bacteremia).

Physical examination shows pallor, alopecia, and ulcerations over the gums. A central venous catheter with entry site in the right upper chest is present but has no surrounding erythema. Physical examination shows pallor, alopecia, and ulcerations over the gums. A central venous catheter with entry site in the right upper chest is present but has no surrounding erythema. metadata.medical_code_description: This question describes febrile neutropenia due to induction chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Cytotoxic chemotherapy suppresses bone marrow myelopoiesis, causing a markedly decreased absolute neutrophil count and impaired innate immune defense (reduced neutrophil-mediated phagocytosis/killing). Concomitant chemotherapy-associated mucositis (e.g., gingival ulcerations) disrupts mucosal barriers, facilitating translocation of gram-negative rods from endogenous flora into the bloodstream—leading to bacteremia despite an uninflamed catheter exit site.

metadata.medical_code_name: Secondary malignant neoplasm of unspecified lung
metadata.medical_code_description: This code is used for metastatic (secondary) cancer deposits in the lung when the lung is not the primary site. In colorectal cancer, tumor cells commonly metastasize first to the liver via the portal venous system, then can reach the lungs by entering systemic venous circulation through the hepatic veins → inferior vena cava → right heart → pulmonary arteries, leading to pulmonary metastases.

metadata.medical_code_name: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia not having achieved remission
metadata.medical_code_description: Malignant neoplasm characterized by acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in which the disease has not achieved remission status.

clinical_rationale.why_this_is_best: High-dose methotrexate inhibits DHFR, preventing conversion of dihydrofolate (DHF) to tetrahydrofolate (THF) and thereby depleting reduced folate needed for thymidylate and purine synthesis. Leucovorin is a reduced folate (5-formyl-THF) that can be converted into active folate cofactors without needing DHFR, restoring DNA/RNA synthesis in normal cells and decreasing methotrexate toxicity.
why_other_enzyme_targets_are_not_as_bene: Thymidylate synthase: this is inhibited by 5-FU, not methotrexate; bypassing it would not directly reverse methotrexate’s DHFR blockade.
Dihydrofolate synthase: this is a bacterial pathway target (e.g., sulfonamides/trimethoprim context); it is not the key mammalian step blocked by methotrexate.

Other purine/pyrimidine synthesis enzymes (e.g., amidophosphoribosyltransferase): methotrexate’s primary lesion is upstream folate reduction; giving leucovorin specifically bypasses the DHFR-dependent requirement rather than targeting downstream enzymes.

question:
A 4082-g (9-lb) male newborn is delivered in the hospital at 40 weeks' gestation to a 28-year-old primigravid woman. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination of the newborn's tongue shows a small blind pit in the midline located near the intersection of the anterior two-thirds and the posterior one-third. Ultrasonography of the neck shows a mass attached to the hyoid bone. Where among these choices does the hormones produced by the mass cells attach to and why? Explan your reasoning for each of the choices.

(B) Ligand-gated ion channels

(E) σ Receptors

question:
A 50-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-month history of increasing daytime somnolence. He has obstructive sleep apnea for which he has only intermittently used a continuous positive airway pressure device. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 181 kg (400 lb); BMI is 63 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a gray-blue tinge to the lips, earlobes, and nail beds. Cardiac examination shows no other abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.31, PCO2 of 70 mm Hg, and PO2 of 50 mm Hg. Which of the following additional findings would be most likely in this patient?

(A) Decreased serum bicarbonate concentration
(B) Increased hemoglobin concentration
(C) Increased total lung capacity
(D) Left ventricular hypertrophy

question:
An obese 35-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination. He has chronic kidney disease and was told to keep a record of his meals until this follow-up visit. His daily diet consists of chocolate milk and a peanut butter sandwich for breakfast; pizza and cola for lunch; a chocolate bar as a snack; and a foot-long deli meat sandwich for dinner. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 113 kg (250 lb); BMI is 42 kg/m². His pulse is 100/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 155/100 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diaphoresis. Serum studies show a creatinine concentration of 4.1 mg/dL and phosphorus concentration of 6 mg/dL. Which of the following patterns is most likely in this patient?

(A) Downregulated parathyroid hormone synthesis, increased serum calcium, increased Serum 1,25- Dihydroxycholecalciferol 
(B) Downregulated parathyroid hormone synthesis, increased serum calcium, decreased Serum 1,25- Dihydroxycholecalciferol
(C) Downregulated parathyroid hormone synthesis, decreased serum calcium, decreased Serum 1,25- Dihydroxycholecalciferol
(D) Upregulated parathyroid hormone synthesis, increased serum calcium, increased Serum 1,25- Dihydroxycholecalciferol
(E) Upregulated parathyroid hormone synthesis, increased serum calcium, decreased Serum 1,25- Dihydroxycholecalciferol
(F) Upregulated parathyroid hormone synthesis, decreased serum calcium, decreased Serum 1,25- Dihydroxycholecalciferol
correct_response: (F) Upregulated parathyroid hormone synthesis, decreased serum calcium, decreased Serum 1,25- Dihydroxycholecalciferol

(F) Upregulated parathyroid hormone synthesis, decreased serum calcium, decreased Serum 1,25- Dihydroxycholecalciferol

metadata.medical_code_description: In chronic kidney disease, reduced phosphate excretion causes hyperphosphatemia (as in this patient). Phosphate binds calcium and CKD also reduces 1-alpha hydroxylation of vitamin D, leading to low 1,25-(OH)2 vitamin D (calcitriol) and decreased intestinal calcium absorption. The net effect is hypocalcemia that chronically stimulates the parathyroid glands → elevated PTH (secondary hyperparathyroidism of renal origin). Expected lab pattern: ↑ phosphate, ↓ calcium, ↓ calcitriol, ↑ PTH (often with high alkaline phosphatase due to renal osteodystrophy). Other patterns are incorrect because they conflict with CKD physiology: (1) ↓ PTH would suggest hypoparathyroidism or suppression (not expected with hyperphosphatemia/hypocalcemia), (2) ↑ calcitriol is unlikely because diseased kidneys cannot adequately convert 25-OH vitamin D to calcitriol, and (3) normal/low phosphate would not fit impaired renal phosphate clearance and the measured phosphorus of 6 mg/dL.

question: An obese 35-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination. He has chronic kidney disease and was told to keep a record of his meals until this follow-up visit. His daily diet consists of chocolate milk and a peanut butter sandwich for breakfast; pizza and cola for lunch; a chocolate bar as a snack; and a foot-long deli meat sandwich for dinner. metadata.medical_code_description: Hyperparathyroidism caused by chronic kidney disease due to impaired phosphate excretion and reduced calcitriol production, leading to hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and compensatory elevation of parathyroid hormone with associated renal osteodystrophy (eg, bone demineralization/subperiosteal resorption) and potential soft-tissue/vascular calcifications.

question:
A 60-year-old woman is nearing the completion of a half marathon. Because she experiences esophageal regurgitation, she does not drink any liquid during the race. This woman's physical state at the end of the race will most likely activate which of the following renal segments at this time?

(A) Arginine vasoreceptor 2 in the proximal tubular cells
(B) K+–H+ exchange in the distal tubule
(C) Proximal tubule carbonic anhydrase
(D) Urea reabsorption in the medullary collecting ducts
(E) Water reabsorption in the ascending loop of Henle
correct_response: (D) Urea reabsorption in the medullary collecting ducts
question_context: A 60-year-old woman is nearing the completion of a half marathon. Because she experiences esophageal regurgitation, she does not drink any liquid during the race. This woman's physical state at the end of the race will most likely activate which of the following renal segments at this time?

(A) Arginine vasoreceptor 2 in the proximal tubular cells
(B) K+–H+ exchange in the distal tubule
(C) Proximal tubule carbonic anhydrase
(D) Urea reabsorption in the medullary collecting ducts
(E) Water reabsorption in the ascending loop of Henle

metadata.medical_code_description: Deficit of total body water (often due to inadequate intake and/or excessive loss), leading to increased plasma osmolality and activation of physiologic water-conserving mechanisms such as ADH-mediated water reabsorption in the late distal tubule and collecting ducts.

question:
A 60-year-old woman is nearing the completion of a half marathon. Because she experiences esophageal regurgitation, she does not drink any liquid during the race. What renal segment would be activated when this woman finishes the race? Explain the rationale for the answer and the other choices as well.

(A) Arginine vasoreceptor 2 in the proximal tubular cells
(B) K+–H+ exchange in the distal tubule
(C) Proximal tubule carbonic anhydrase
(D) Urea reabsorption in the medullary collecting ducts
(E) Water reabsorption in the ascending loop of Henle
correct_response: (D) Urea reabsorption in the medullary collecting ducts
question_context: A 60-year-old woman is nearing the completion of a half marathon. Because she experiences esophageal regurgitation, she does not drink any liquid during the race. What renal segment would be activated when this woman finishes the race? Explain the rationale for the answer and the other choices as well.
options:
(A) Arginine vasoreceptor 2 in the proximal tubular cells
(B) K+–H+ exchange in the distal tubule
(C) Proximal tubule carbonic anhydrase
(D) Urea reabsorption in the medullary collecting ducts
(E) Water reabsorption in the ascending loop of Henle

metadata.medical_code_description: Loss of body water (and often electrolytes) resulting in reduced total body fluid volume; commonly due to inadequate intake and/or excessive losses (e.g., sweating during prolonged exertion).
metadata.rationale: Finishing a half marathon without drinking leads to increased plasma osmolality and decreased effective circulating volume from sweat losses. This stimulates ADH release (and also RAAS). ADH primarily acts on the collecting duct principal cells (late distal tubule/cortical collecting duct and medullary collecting duct) via V2 receptors to insert aquaporin-2 channels, increasing water reabsorption and concentrating urine. Other nephron segments are less directly ‘activated’ by ADH: the proximal tubule reabsorbs iso-osmotically and is not the main regulated site for rapid water conservation; the thin descending limb is water-permeable but not hormonally activated; the thick ascending limb and early distal convoluted tubule are largely water-impermeable (diluting segments), so they cannot directly increase water reabsorption in response to dehydration.

question: A 60-year-old woman is nearing the completion of a half marathon. Because she experiences esophageal regurgitation, she does not drink any liquid during the race. What renal segment would be activated with this woman's physical state at the end of the race?
correct_response: (D) Urea reabsorption in the medullary collecting ducts
question_context: A 60-year-old woman is nearing the completion of a half marathon. Because she experiences esophageal regurgitation, she does not drink any liquid during the race. What renal segment would be activated with this woman's physical state at the end of the race?

metadata.medical_code_description: A state of body water deficit (often from inadequate fluid intake and/or excessive losses such as sweating during prolonged exercise), leading to increased renal water conservation (e.g., via ADH acting primarily on the late distal tubule and collecting ducts).

question:
A 32-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-week history of fever and throat pain. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (140 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. His pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 98/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows scattered 2- to 4-cm lymph nodes in the neck, axillae, and inguinal regions. There is a bilateral tonsillar exudate but no ulcerations. Results of laboratory studies are shown: 
Hemoglobin 9.6 g/dL
Hematocrit 29%
Leukocyte count 1500/mm³
Platelet count  60,000/mm³

A heterophile antibody test result is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

(A)  Epstein-Barr virus infection 
(B)  Gonococcal pharyngitis 
(C)  HIV infection 
(D)  Lymphogranuloma venereum infection 
(E)  Streptococcal pharyngitis

metadata.medical_code_description: Acute (primary) HIV infection presenting as an EBV-like mononucleosis syndrome. This patient’s 2-week history of fever and exudative pharyngitis with generalized lymphadenopathy plus marked cytopenias (anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia) and a negative heterophile antibody test makes acute HIV infection syndrome more likely than EBV infectious mononucleosis (typically heterophile-positive) and supports early HIV-related marrow/immune effects during seroconversion.

question:
A 51-year-old man with a 10-year history of gastroesophageal reflux and suspected Barrett esophagus comes to the office because his omeprazole dose "doesn't work around the Christmas holidays." He states that he prides himself on having a large appetite and "holding his liquor" during the holidays. He currently takes the maximum dose of omeprazole. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?

(A) Ask the patient how much he is eating and drinking during the holidays
(B) Explain the hazards of untreated reflux in the presence of Barrett esophagus
(C) Order an upper endoscopy
(D) Refer the patient to a gastroenterologist
(E) Switch the omeprazole to pantoprazole
correct_response: (A) Ask the patient how much he is eating and drinking during the holidays

question:
A 60-year-old man comes to the office because of weakness, tingling of his hands and feet, irritability, and forgetfulness for 4 months. Physical examination shows pallor, weakness, and spasticity. Deep tendon reflexes are increased. Sensation to vibration is absent in the lower extremities. Laboratory studies show megaloblastic anemia, serum antiparietal cell antibodies, and increased serum concentrations of methylmalonic acid and total homocyst(e)ine. The synthesis of which of the following amino acids is most likely impaired in this patient?

(A) Cysteine
(B) Glutamine 
(C) Methionine 
(D) Phenylalanine 
(E) Tyrosine

question:
A 12-year-old girl is brought to the office because of a 2-day history of chest pain. She also had a 3-day history of fever that has since resolved. When she lies down, the pain worsens and she has shortness of breath. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). A friction rub is heard. Which of the following is the most likely causal infectious agent?

(A) Coxsackievirus
(B) Mumps virus
(C) Staphylococcus aureus
(D) Staphylococcus epidermidis
(E) Viridans streptococcus

metadata.medical_code_description: Acute inflammation of the pericardial sac due to an infectious etiology (most commonly viral in children/adolescents, classically Coxsackievirus B). Pathology involves acute pericardial inflammation with fibrinous/serofibrinous exudate and pericardial surface irritation, producing a pericardial friction rub and sharp, pleuritic chest pain that worsens when supine (and typically improves when sitting up/leaning forward); may be accompanied by a small pericardial effusion.

question: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the office because of a 2-day history of chest pain. She also had a 3-day history of fever that has since resolved. When she lies down, the pain worsens and she has shortness of breath. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). A friction rub is heard. What is the etiologic agent for this case and explain the pathology behind the case?
question_context: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the office because of a 2-day history of chest pain. She also had a 3-day history of fever that has since resolved. When she lies down, the pain worsens and she has shortness of breath. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). A friction rub is heard. What is the etiologic agent for this case and explain the pathology behind the case?

metadata.medical_code_description: Acute pericardial inflammation due to a viral infection—classically Coxsackievirus B (enterovirus) in children/adolescents. Viral infection triggers inflammatory injury of the pericardium with serofibrinous exudate and fibrin deposition, producing a pericardial friction rub and pleuritic, sharp chest pain that worsens when supine (greater contact/stretch of the inflamed pericardial layers) and may improve when sitting up/leaning forward. Can be associated with pericardial effusion and, if severe, cardiac tamponade.

question:
A 32-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-day history of cough productive of small amounts of blood and a 2-day history of shortness of breath and swelling of his ankles. He also has a 2-week history of progressive fatigue and episodes of dark urine. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 175/110 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Diffuse inspiratory crackles are heard over all lung bases. There is 2+ pitting edema of both ankles. 

Results of laboratory studies are shown:

Hemoglobin 8.9 g/dL
Hematocrit  27%
Serum 
   Urea nitrogen 55 mg/dL
   Creatinine 2.9 mg/dL
Urine RBC 20–40/hpf 
 
Urinalysis also shows some dysmorphic RBCs and rare RBC casts. Examination of a kidney biopsy specimen shows crescentic glomerulonephritis and linear deposition of IgG along the glomerular capillaries. This patient most likely has antibodies directed against which of the following antigens? 
(A)  Collagen 
(B)  Double-stranded DNA 
(C)  Nucleolar protein 
(D)  Phospholipid 
(E)  Proteins in neutrophil cytoplasm

metadata.medical_code_description: Anti–glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease characterized by rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis with linear IgG deposition along glomerular capillaries, often accompanied by pulmonary hemorrhage/hemoptysis due to antibodies against the α3 chain of type IV collagen in basement membranes.

metadata.medical_code_description: Autoimmune anti–basement membrane disease causing rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis with linear IgG deposition along glomerular capillary walls and often concurrent pulmonary hemorrhage. Pathogenic IgG targets the NC1 domain of the α3 chain of type IV collagen found in glomerular and alveolar basement membranes; epithelial/endothelial injury (e.g., smoking, respiratory infection, hydrocarbon exposure) can expose/alter this antigen, triggering autoantibody formation and complement-mediated inflammation.

Urinalysis also shows some dysmorphic RBCs and rare RBC casts. Examination of a kidney biopsy specimen shows crescentic glomerulonephritis and linear deposition of IgG along the glomerular capillaries. What antigens has antibodies directing against it for this patient and explain how it happened?

metadata.medical_code_description: Autoimmune anti–glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease causing rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis and often pulmonary hemorrhage/hemoptysis due to antibodies directed against the noncollagenous (NC1) domain of the alpha-3 chain of type IV collagen found in the GBM and alveolar basement membrane. This is a type II (antibody-mediated) hypersensitivity reaction; injury (often after triggers such as respiratory infections, smoking, or hydrocarbon exposure) is thought to expose/alter basement membrane epitopes, leading to IgG autoantibody formation and characteristic linear IgG deposition on immunofluorescence.

question:
A 58-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the clinic with his wife for a follow-up examination. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He has tried to quit smoking twice but was unsuccessful both times. At today’s visit, when the physician asks the patient about smoking cessation, he says he is not ready to do so. The patient’s wife states her husband’s smoking makes her cough and gives her chest tightness. Which of the following is the most appropriate physician statement?

(A) "Are there any reasons why you might want to quit smoking?"
(B) "Are you aware that your lung condition is chronic at this point?"
(C) "I'm sure you don't want your wife to suffer as a result of your smoking."
(D) "The majority of your health issues would improve if you quit smoking."
(E) "Why haven't you been able to stay off cigarettes?"
correct_response: (A) "Are there any reasons why you might want to quit smoking?"

(C) "I'm sure you don't want your wife to suffer as a result of your smoking."

question:
A 58-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the clinic with his wife for a follow-up examination. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He has tried to quit smoking twice but was unsuccessful both times. At today’s visit, when the physician asks the patient about smoking cessation, he says he is not ready to do so. The patient’s wife states her husband’s smoking makes her cough and gives her chest tightness. What statement would be the most appropriate for the physician to tell the patient and why?

(A) "Are there any reasons why you might want to quit smoking?"
(B) "Are you aware that your lung condition is chronic at this point?"
(C) "I'm sure you don't want your wife to suffer as a result of your smoking."
(D) "The majority of your health issues would improve if you quit smoking."
(E) "Why haven't you been able to stay off cigarettes?"
correct_response: (A) "Are there any reasons why you might want to quit smoking?"

question:
A 26-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-week history of increased urinary frequency accompanied by excessive thirst. He says he has been urinating hourly. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum chemistry studies are within the reference ranges. Urine osmolality is 50 mOsmol/kg H2O. After administration of ADH (vasopressin), his urine osmolality is within the reference range. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is dysfunction of which of the following structures?

(A) Anterior pituitary gland
(B) Bowman capsule
(C) Glomerulus
(D) Hypophysial portal system
(E) Loop of Henle
(F) Supraoptic nucleus

metadata.medical_code_description: A disorder of antidiuretic hormone (ADH/vasopressin) regulation characterized by inability to concentrate urine, leading to polyuria and polydipsia. In central diabetes insipidus, ADH production or release from the hypothalamic–posterior pituitary axis is impaired, and urine osmolality increases after exogenous vasopressin.

metadata.medical_code_description: Findings (polyuria/polydipsia, very low urine osmolality ~50 mOsm/kg, and normalization of urine osmolality after exogenous vasopressin) indicate central diabetes insipidus due to impaired synthesis or release of ADH from the hypothalamic supraoptic/paraventricular nuclei and/or the posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis). ADH deficiency prevents insertion of aquaporin-2 channels in the collecting ducts, causing inability to concentrate urine; giving vasopressin restores collecting-duct water reabsorption and raises urine osmolality into the reference range.

question: A 26-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-week history of increased urinary frequency accompanied by excessive thirst. He says he has been urinating hourly. metadata.medical_code_description: Central diabetes insipidus due to impaired synthesis/transport/release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from hypothalamic supraoptic/paraventricular nuclei or the posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis). Low ADH prevents aquaporin-2 insertion in renal collecting ducts, causing inability to concentrate urine (very low urine osmolality) and resulting polyuria with compensatory polydipsia; urine osmolality normalizes after exogenous vasopressin.

question:
A 19-year-old man who is in the US Army is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after he sustained a knife wound to the right side of his chest during an altercation. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. On physical examination, the trachea appears to be shifted to the left. Pulmonary examination of the right chest is most likely to show which of the following findings? 

(A) Decreased Fremitus, dull Percussion, decreased breath sounds 
(B) Decreased Fremitus, hyperresonant Percussion, decreased breath sounds 
(C) Decreased Fremitus, hyperresonant Percussion, dull breath sounds 
(D) Increased Fremitus, dull Percussion, bronchial breath sounds 
(E) Increased Fremitus, dull Percussion, decreased breath sounds
correct_response: (B) Decreased Fremitus, hyperresonant Percussion, decreased breath sounds

metadata.medical_code_description: Air in the pleural space due to trauma (eg, penetrating chest injury such as a knife wound), presenting during the initial encounter for treatment; may cause decreased/absent breath sounds and hyperresonance on the affected side, and can progress to tension physiology with tracheal deviation away from the injured side.
